Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 44122-013 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
November 2019 
 
 
 
Knowledge and Support in Sovereign Asset and 
Liability Management
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to 
Information Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ALM  –  asset and liability management 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  IMF  –  International Monetary Fund 
  PDM  –  public debt management 
  RAMP  –  Reserves Advisory and Management Program 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  UNCTAD  –  United Nations Conference on Trade and Development

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) aims to strengthen the institutional capacity of policymakers and technical experts in the 
area of sovereign asset and liability management (ALM) by deepening the technical skills for 
analyzing the interlinkages between public debt and reserve management. While public debt 
management (PDM) and reserve management are often viewed in isolation, there is significant 
merit in taking a holistic ALM perspective to optimize public sector financial management and 
reduce risks such as currency or maturity mismatches. ADB’s Treasury Department is uniquely 
placed  to  conduct  this  TA  because  it  gained  significant  experience  in  PDM  and  reserve 
management and developed an extensive network of contacts with decision-makers in finance 
ministries and central banks under two ongoing TA projects, the Asian Regional Public Debt 
Management  Forums  and  Workshops,  and  the  Asian  Regional  Forum  on  Investment 
Management of Foreign Exchange Reserves.1 While the earlier TA work focuses on knowledge 
exchange through forums, ADB’s Treasury Department proposes this TA to provide in-country 
assistance on sovereign ALM. It is meant to complement the PDM and reserve management 
initiatives of ADB’s regional departments, and the Treasury Department will coordinate the TA 
activities with these departments.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Effective and sound PDM is a cornerstone of robust economic policy. PDM is defined as 
the process of establishing and implementing a strategy for managing a government’s debt to 
meet its financing needs, taking into account its cost and risk objectives. Effective and sound PDM 
is typically characterized by the following elements:2 
 
(i)  The core strategy. A medium-term, annually updated PDM strategy with links to 
macroeconomic  policy  is  in  place  and  covers aspects  such  as  the  currency 
composition  of  public  debt,  the  mix  of  domestic  and  external  debt,  maturity 
structure and minimum liquidity targets, the mix of fixed-rate and floating-rate 
borrowings, and an analysis of borrowing strategies in a cost-risk framework.  
(ii)  Sound governance and institutional framework. A sound legal and institutional 
framework  assigns  responsibilities  for  implementing  the  PDM  strategy  and 
provides accountability and transparency. Office arrangements such as back office, 
middle office, and front office are in place.  
(iii)  Effective  risk  management  strategy.  A  risk  management  framework  for 
monitoring, scenario modeling, performance benchmarks, and limits is in place. 
(iv)  Integrated  information  technology  infrastructure.  A  debt  recording  and 
management system that allows the management of public debt is in place.3 
 
3.  Reserve management, which is the preserve of central banks, is key to ensuring that  
adequate official public sector foreign assets are available to meet a defined range of objectives. 
For instance, such objectives call for limiting a country’s external vulnerability by maintaining 
 
1 ADB.  2015.  Asian  Regional  Public  Debt  Management  Forums  and  Workshops.  Manila  (regional—capacity 
development TA. Project no. 49282-001) and ADB. 2015. Asian Regional Forum on Investment Management of 
Foreign Exchange Reserves. Manila (regional—capacity development TA. Project no. 49298-001).  
2  G. Wheeler. 2004. Sound Practice in Government Debt Management. Washington, DC: World Bank. 
3  The two most commonly used systems are the Debt Management and Financial Analysis System by the United 
Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) and the Commonwealth Secretariat’s Debt Management 
and Recording System.

2 
foreign currency liquidity to absorb economic shocks and provide assurance to capital markets 
that  the  country  can  meet  its  foreign  exchange  needs.  Sound  reserve  management  is 
characterized by the following elements:4 
 
(i)  Reserve management strategy and policy. Strategy and policy spell out the 
objectives of holding reserves, and include investment objectives, risk–return 
considerations,  eligible  asset  classes,  liquidity  tranching,  and  internal  versus 
external management. 
(ii)  Internal governance and organizational structure. A legislative framework is in 
place, and the reserve management department has an institutional structure with 
front,  middle,  and  back  offices;  clearly  delineated  areas  of  responsibilities; 
supervisory bodies such as investment and risk committees; and regular internal 
audits.  
(iii)  Risk management framework. A well-defined framework identifies risks, such 
as liquidity, market, credit, and operational risks; and establishes the parameters 
within which these risks shall be managed.  
(iv)  Systems support. This enables effective and efficient investment management 
and best-practice risk management, and provides regular management reports 
that allow stakeholders to receive up-to-date and comprehensive information.                               
 
4.  While PDM and reserve management are often viewed in isolation, modern approaches 
recognize that both need to be seen in a holistic, sovereign ALM context. Viewing PDM without 
including sovereign assets, for example, runs the risk of not recognizing potentials for risk 
reduction through natural hedging on the sovereign balance sheet. In practice, since the two areas 
are typically handled by two different branches of the government (reserve management by the 
central bank and PDM by the finance ministry), they often reveal institutional gaps, insufficient 
coordination, and the lack of an agreed framework or even basic principles on how these issues 
should be coordinated.  
 
5.  This TA will focus on providing an integrated view of sovereign ALM issues, connecting 
sovereign financial assets with sovereign liabilities and analyzing optimization and risk hedging 
of the sovereign balance sheet from an ALM perspective. Sovereign ALM is a relatively new area 
in the developing member country (DMC) context. ADB has been organizing debt management 
forums since 2009 and reserve management forums since 2011. As part of these, ADB carried 
out surveys of existing practices of PDM, reserve management, and sovereign ALM. These 
surveys found that sovereign ALM is not widely practiced in most of ADB’s DMCs.  
  
6.  Other development organizations do not cover the area of sovereign ALM and focus 
mostly on PDM. Leading in the area of PDM is the World Bank Treasury, which established the 
Government Debt and Risk Management Program in 2011. Funded by the Swiss State Secretariat 
of Economic Affairs, the program provides customized technical advisory services to strengthen 
public debt and risk management capacity but is aimed exclusively at middle-income countries. 
Only three countries from the Asia and Pacific region are currently participating in this program.5 
Since 2008, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) jointly manage the Debt 
Management  Facility,  which  traditionally  focused  on  lower-income  countries.  The  facility 
concentrates on debt management issues but does not include sovereign ALM. In the area of 
 
4  International Monetary Fund (IMF). 2014. Revised Guidelines for Foreign Exchange Management, Washington, DC. 
5  Azerbaijan, Indonesia, and Viet Nam. The April 2019 implementation report for phase 1 of the program: 
https://treasury.worldbank.org/en/about/unit/treasury/client-services/government-debt-risk-management-program

3 
reserve management, the two main sources of technical assistance are the Bank for International 
Settlements and the World Bank’s Reserves Advisory and Management Program (RAMP).6 
However, in order to be eligible to participate for the advisory and capacity-building components, 
a DMC is required to deposit a minimum amount of liquidity for asset management purposes.7 In 
the area of sovereign ALM, the donor community has launched two initiatives. First, the Dept 
Management  Department  of  the  United  Nations  Conference  on  Trade  and  Development 
(UNCTAD)  conducted  a  TA  project  on  sovereign  ALM  that  included  country  and  regional 
workshops but was limited to Africa and Latin America.8 Second, the World Bank developed a 
training program that looks at sovereign balance sheet management. The program is comparable 
to the TA but is fee-based and targeted at middle-income countries that are willing to pay for the 
advisory services. ADB and World Bank Treasury staff discussed the topic of sovereign ALM and 
agreed on close coordination to avoid duplications, ensure complementarity, share lessons, and 
optimize knowledge transfer.  
 
7.  The TA is aligned with a key operational priority of ADB’s Strategy 20309—strengthening 
governance and institutional capacity10—which highlights that good governance and strong 
institutional capacity are the basis for country development. Strategy 2030 notes that ADB will 
help strengthen the quality and capacity of public institutions to undertake policy reforms. The TA 
falls directly into this focal area of Strategy 2030.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA will have the following impact: enhanced institutional sovereign ALM capacity. It 
will have the following outcome: more resilient debt and reserve management and improved 
macroeconomic management. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  The TA activities will include  
(i)  country diagnostic assessments to benchmark PDM and reserve management in 
the context of a sovereign ALM approach against international best practices;  
(ii)  in-depth analysis, recommendations, and an implementation time plan to enhance 
existing standards and practices; and  
(iii)  assistance in implementing the recommendations.  
 
ADB benefits from these activities through client feedback on how to enhance its financial 
products and strengthen its relevance in the region.  
 
10.  ADB’s Treasury Department will cooperate with regional departments to identify the 
participating DMCs. The objective is to achieve broad geographic representation. It is expected 
 
6  More information on the RAMP is provided under this link: 
https://treasury.worldbank.org/en/about/unit/treasury/client-services/reserves-advisory-and-management-
partnership (accessed 13 November 2019). 
7  RAMP requires a $100 million minimum to be placed with the World Bank Treasury for asset management purposes.  
8 Sovereign  asset  and  liability  management:  https://unctad.org/en/Pages/GDS/Sovereign-Debt-Portal/Sovereign-
Asset-and-Liability-Management.aspx (accessed 12 November 2019). 
9 ADB. 2019. Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 7: Fostering Regional Cooperation and Integration, 2019– 
2024. Manila. 
10 ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila.

4 
that about 5–6 DMCs can be included. DMCs need to commit staff resources for the assistance 
to succeed. Each DMC will be responsible for indicating its development priorities, agree to a 
sequencing of reforms, and spearhead the implementation of the reforms. 
 
11.  Output 1: Completion of assessments related to PDM, reserve management in a 
sovereign ALM context. The diagnostic assessment of PDM will follow the World Bank’s debt 
management performance assessment methodology, a system for reviewing indicators crucial to 
effective PDM and sovereign ALM. In the area of reserve management, the IMF’s 2014 Revised 
Guidelines on Reserve Management shall form the basis for the country diagnostic assessment. 
The  guidelines  identify areas  of  agreement  between  practitioners  on  reserve management 
principles and best practices. No generally accepted framework on sovereign ALM exists, but 
recent work from the IMF and other debt management offices has laid out principles in this area11 
that will form the basis of the country diagnostic assessments. The studies under this output 
should pinpoint opportunities to strengthen both public debt and reserve management and 
highlight their interdependencies in the context of sovereign ALM. They should include a set of 
policy recommendations and an action plan with a timeline.  
 
12.  Output 2: Completion of a synthesis report on the implementation of the TA. A 
synthesis report should be prepared that reports on the progress made across the participating 
DMCs.  
 
13.  Output 3: Accomplishment of technical capacity building in sovereign asset and 
liability  management.  On  request  by  the  participating  DMCs,  the  TA  team  will  organize 
workshops to facilitate knowledge exchange. These events will target staff involved in reserve 
management and PDM. By organizing these workshops jointly with central banks and finance 
ministries,  institutional  gaps  can  be  bridged  to  achieve  a  more  symbiotic  sovereign  ALM 
approach. Experts from pertinent organizations—e.g., the World Bank, the IMF, the Organisation 
for Economic Co-operation and Development, PDM system providers, academia, members from 
DMCs’ parliamentary budget committees, and rating agencies—will be invited to participate in the 
discussions. Workshops may be organized with other development partners to tap into their 
experience and may include peer-to-peer learning from speakers from other DMCs that are willing 
to share knowledge. Workshops will also include training and capacity building on ADB’s Debt 
Management Products that can be instrumental in implementing a sovereign’s asset-liability 
management strategy.12  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000, to be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). Key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2.  
ADB will be the executing and implementing agency, and ADB’s Treasury Department will 
administer the TA and supervise the TA consultants. The TA will be implemented in consultation 
with ADB’s regional departments, Strategy and Policy Department, Economic Research and 
Regional Cooperation Department, Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department, 
and other relevant departments and ADB’s finance sector group, and will follow the “One ADB” 
approach. 
 
 
11 For example: https://www.imf.org/external/np/pp/eng/2014/061014.pdf and 
https://unctad.org/en/PublicationsLibrary/gdsddf2014misc1_en.pdf 
12 Such Debt Management Products were introduced by ADB in 2006 and include the option to undertake currency and 
interest rate management transactions with respect to a sovereign’s third-party liabilities.

5 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  The TA will be implemented from 1 January 2020 to 31 December 2022. It will include at 
least five country diagnostic assessments and a synthesis report on optimizing sovereign ALM. A 
no-objection letter will be obtained prior to the commencement or financing of any undertaking in 
the territory of any DMC participating in this TA. The TA will be disbursed in accordance with 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The 
implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation  1 January 2020 to 31 December 2022

Disbursement  TA resources will be disbursed following ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, TA = technical assistance. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
16.  Consulting services. The TA will require an estimated 18 person-months of consulting 
services  from  international  experts  (sovereign  ALM  specialists  (one  or  more  consultants, 
18 person-months)). ADB will engage the consultants following its Procurement Policy (2017, as 
amended from time to time) and its project administration instructions and/or staff instructions.13  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis for 
Knowledge and Support in Sovereign Asset and Liability Management, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.  
 
 
13 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Country diagnostics assessments related to PDM, reserve management in a sovereign ALM context 
1.1  Identify the first three DMCs that are willing to participate in this TA by the second quarter (Q2) of 2020  
1.2  Obtain no-objection letters from participating Asian Development Bank DMCs by Q2 2020 
1.3  Engage consultants by Q2 2020 
1.4  Start country diagnostics studies by Q2 2020 
1.5  Complete country diagnostic studies by Q4 2020 
1.6  Identify another 2–3 DMCs that are interested in participating in the study by Q4 2020 
1.7  Complete country diagnostic studies by Q4 2021 
1.8  Summarize findings of country diagnostic studies in TA synthesis report by Q4 2022 
2.  Technical capacity building in sovereign ALM accomplished 
2.1  First workshop and/or peer-to-peer learning events held (Q4 2020) 
2.2  At least five workshops and/or peer-to-peer learning events held in participating DMCs (Q4 2022)
